title: Strictly's Oti and Motsi Mabuse faced racism finding dance teachers
text:
The sisters found it ‘really tough’ to succeed (Picture: Getty)

Strictly Come Dancing’s Motsi Mabuse has revealed that she and her sister Oti struggled to find dance teachers in South Africa as children because of racial prejudice.

The judge, who has quickly become a beloved member of the panel, opened up about it being ‘really tough’ for the both of them to succeed.

‘Finding people to give us the instructions was difficult. It was a very difficult time in South Africa, so to be a little girl and push yourself in this type of dancing, where there are no other black girls, was really tough,’ she explained.

Oti has been wowing viewers with her partner Kelvin Fletcher (Picture: BBC)

The 38-year-old added to The Mirror: ‘And when we did get the chance to learn the waltz and the cha cha cha, at a weekend club, we were soon better than the teacher.’

Definitely not hard to believe.

The sisters, who are going up against each other at the NTAs next year, first discovered their passion for dancing when they saw a couples’ ballroom competition while they were on holiday in Durban, before begging their mother to let them learn.

Motsi added that their parents made ‘a lot of sacrifices’ due to dancing being an expensive sport.

‘I’m so thankful for dance because if I had grown up with just the bitterness of the very hard childhood we had, and I’d never experienced the love of the dance world, then I probably would have been a very sad person,’ she explained.

Motsi has quickly become a beloved member of the judging panel (Picture: BBC One)

While Oti has been part of the Strictly family since 2015, wowing fans with her choreography, Motsi joined the judging panel this year.

However, it hasn’t been a smooth journey, as she faced backlash about working with her sister.

‘Once you’ve been in the public eye, you are always going to be criticised,’ she told Good Housekeeping.

‘Strictly is the master of all dance programmes. It’s so big! I’ve been watching the German show grow, but in the UK, I’m coming in when it’s already huge!….You learn not to take things personally, but it can be hard.’
